comments:
I200303272130

1) Install Eclipse Platform (runime binary only)
2) Launch eclipse  and shut down eclipse. Can repeat multiple times with no problem.
3) Install JDT.  
I am using IE so to do this I delete the Eclipse.1 folder IE created and I unzip the zip file
overtop of the existing eclipse directry.
4) Launch eclipse  and shut down eclipse.  No problem.
5) Launch eclipse again, get following NPE:

Is this a consequence of the launching plugin being disabled ?

This looks related to bug 35778. It looks like a configuration problem (i.e. 
missing plug-ins).

However (on a second look), the NPE does not appear to have anything to do with 
JDT.

The disabled plugin problem is explained in bug 35778.
The NPE happens in org.eclipse.ui - moving to Platform UI for further 
investigation.

When I do a similar test on Windows, I get an update dialog on step 4.  I do 
not see this mentioned here.  Will try on mac.

I don't think this is a "critical" problem.
The steps to reproduce don't reflect a very likely use case on MacOS X.

We (Silenio and I) are unable to reproduce this problem.
Were there more steps?

Mac does -noupdate so you don't get the update manager on restart.  see bug 
35809 for more details.
I could not reproduce in Veronika's machine either.

The NPE is apparently due to incorrect handling of errors when restoring 
editors.  EditorManager.busyRestoreEditor does:
    ref.getPane().createChildControl();
but the pane is null because the editor was not restored properly.

Based on where this error occurs, it should continue to open Eclipse, but the 
workbench layout will be reset.

I don't think this is related to the disabled plugin, since the JDT plugins 
were incomplete and should not have been capable of opening any editors.

Veronika, were there any other editors open?  Presumably the Welcome editor was 
open on first run, but it should have been able to be restored OK.
Is this still an issue for 3.0?

The code in this area has changed, but EditorManager.busyRestoreEditor still
assumes that ref.getPane() is not null.

See also Bug 76672.  A very particular order of events is causing a 
NullPointerException.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 76672 ***
